Inference: Consistently high setpoints indicate preference for hotter water
Description: If historical temperature settings cluster near the upper allowed range, it suggests users systematically prefer hotter water for their faucet or showerhead.
short rationale: Strongly profiles hot-water comfort preference.

Inference: Consistently low setpoints indicate comfort with cooler water
Description: When temperature settings remain near the lower range over time, it implies users are comfortable with cooler water, possibly due to climate, health, or habit.
short rationale: Reveals cooler preference potentially tied to health or habit.

Inference: Narrow temperature band reflects stable comfort preference
Description: Minimal variation around a small temperature window indicates a strong, stable comfort point that users rarely adjust.
short rationale: Shows precise comfort point usable for re-identification.

Inference: Wide temperature swings suggest diverse use cases or users
Description: Frequent large shifts between low and high setpoints indicate multiple use cases or multiple users with different preferences.
short rationale: Hints at multiple users or tasks, moderate identifiability.

Inference: Increasing average setpoint over time indicates warming preference drift
Description: A gradual upward trend in historical temperature settings shows that the typical chosen temperature is rising, suggesting users are slowly preferring warmer water.
short rationale: Tracks evolving comfort drift over time.

Inference: Decreasing average setpoint over time indicates cooling preference drift
Description: A long-term downward trend in setpoints implies users are deliberately choosing cooler temperatures, potentially due to comfort change, safety concerns, or seasonal adaptation.
short rationale: Shows sustained cooling shift tied to behavior or safety.

Inference: Morning peaks in setpoint temperatures suggest hotter water for wake-up routines
Description: When higher temperature selections cluster in morning hours, it indicates users prefer hotter water during wake-up or early hygiene routines.
short rationale: Reveals morning routine timing and intensity.

Inference: Evening peaks in setpoint temperatures suggest hotter water for relaxation
Description: Higher temperatures predominantly chosen in the evening suggest users associate hot water with relaxation or end-of-day routines.
short rationale: Shows evening routine patterns and comfort choices.

Inference: Midday moderate setpoints imply quick, functional usage
Description: If midday setpoints hover in a mid-range, distinct from morning/evening peaks, it suggests more functional, less comfort-focused use during those hours.
short rationale: Functional pattern with limited re-identification.

Inference: Weekend temperature patterns differing from weekdays reveal schedule-driven comfort
Description: A distinct shift in typical setpoints on weekends indicates that temperature choices are influenced by non-workday routines.
short rationale: Shows weekday/weekend routine differences.

Inference: Seasonal increase in setpoints during colder months indicates climate-driven adjustment
Description: Higher typical temperatures in colder seasons reflect users compensating for ambient temperature with hotter water.
short rationale: Seasonal adaptation with moderate identifiability.

Inference: Seasonal decrease in setpoints during hotter months indicates heat-avoidance behavior
Description: Lower preferred setpoints during hot seasons suggest users intentionally choose cooler water to offset environmental heat.
short rationale: Seasonal cooling behavior with limited identity risk.

Inference: Frequent small adjustments around a target value indicate fine-tuning for comfort
Description: Many minor up/down changes within a narrow band during a single session suggest users are actively tuning temperature to reach an exact comfort point.
short rationale: Shows active fine-tuning behavior within sessions.

Inference: Infrequent adjustments indicate set-and-forget behavior
Description: If temperature settings remain unchanged for long periods, it implies users rarely interact with temperature controls once a comfortable baseline is found.
short rationale: Low interaction pattern with limited personal detail.

Inference: Sudden large jumps in setpoint indicate discrete task-specific settings
Description: Occasional large shifts suggest distinct operational modes such as hot cleaning versus cool rinsing rather than incremental comfort adjustments.
short rationale: Reveals task-driven changes, moderate profiling.

Inference: Frequent rapid changes during a single session indicate difficulty finding comfort
Description: A pattern of many consecutive temperature changes within a short time implies the user struggles to reach a satisfactory temperature.
short rationale: Captures comfort struggle during a session.

Inference: User-specific temperature profiles emerge from recurring patterns
Description: Repeated reuse of the same few temperature values over many days suggests identifiable preference profiles even without explicit user IDs.
short rationale: Strongly re-identifies users via preference signature.

Inference: Asymmetric adjustment behavior reveals directional bias
Description: If increases in setpoint are more common than decreases, or vice versa, it suggests users generally feel the default is too cold or too hot.
short rationale: Shows directional preference bias tied to routines.

Inference: Clustered use of a small set of preset values indicates reliance on defaults
Description: If most historical settings match a limited set of discrete temperatures, it implies users heavily rely on preset or recommended values.
short rationale: Preset reliance with low personal specificity.

Inference: Gradual stabilization after installation reflects learning and adaptation
Description: High variability in early temperature changes followed by a stable band suggests that users initially explored the range, then converged on preferred settings.
short rationale: Learning curve insight with modest identity exposure.

Inference: Persistent high maximum setpoints suggest latent scalding risk tolerance
Description: Regular use of very high temperatures indicates users accept or expect near-scalding temperatures, relevant for risk assessment.
short rationale: Shows tolerance for very hot water, notable personal trait.

Inference: Avoidance of extreme setpoints indicates conservative temperature behavior
Description: If temperature history never approaches the extremes, it suggests users intentionally stay within a comfortable and perceived safe mid-range.
short rationale: Conservative behavior with limited re-identification.

Inference: Distinct temperature distributions across fixtures indicate room-specific roles
Description: If one faucet consistently shows cooler setpoints and another hotter, it implies different functional roles purely from their temperature histories.
short rationale: Reveals location-specific roles and preferences.

Inference: Abrupt long-term shift in typical setpoints signals lifestyle or occupant change
Description: A sudden, sustained change in the baseline temperature level implies a major shift, such as a new occupant or changed routine.
short rationale: Indicates occupancy/lifestyle change.

Inference: High day-to-day variability in temperatures indicates irregular usage patterns
Description: When average daily setpoints fluctuate widely, it suggests inconsistent routines, varying tasks, or changing environmental conditions.
short rationale: Shows irregular routines across days.

Inference: Low day-to-day variability indicates highly routinized use
Description: Small differences in daily temperature statistics imply very stable, habitual use with little deviation from established comfort norms.
short rationale: Highly routinized behavior useful for profiling.

Inference: Correlated temperature changes at similar times each day reveal structured rituals
Description: Repeating patterns of setpoints at similar times each day show structured, time-anchored routines.
short rationale: Strongly exposes daily rituals and timing.

Inference: Short bursts of unusually low temperatures suggest intentional cold-water events
Description: Occasional clearly lower-than-normal setpoints within an otherwise warm pattern indicate specific cold-water use cases.
short rationale: Identifies intentional cold-use episodes.

Inference: Short bursts of unusually high temperatures suggest intensive thermal tasks
Description: One-off use of very high temperatures amidst moderate patterns suggests infrequent but intense thermal tasks like hot cleaning or disinfection.
short rationale: Highlights infrequent hot tasks at specific times.

Inference: Convergence to mid-range values after extremes indicates safety-driven correction
Description: If users briefly set extremely high or low temperatures and quickly return to mid-range values, it suggests exploratory changes followed by a return to perceived safe levels.
short rationale: Shows cautious correction with low identity risk.

Inference: Multiple distinct temperature modes imply scenario-based usage
Description: Temperature histories that cluster into multiple discrete bands indicate scenario-based use even without explicit labels.
short rationale: Reveals scenario clusters, moderate identifiability.

Inference: Reduced frequency of changes during certain periods signals confidence in defaults
Description: Time windows where temperature changes are rare, despite frequent activations, indicate that the existing setting is trusted.
short rationale: Indicates trusted defaults; limited personal detail.

Inference: Increased change frequency after configuration updates implies user re-adaptation
Description: A noticeable spike in temperature adjustments after a configuration shift suggests users are re-tuning their comfort levels.
short rationale: Shows re-adaptation period, modest exposure.

Inference: Persistent drift without stabilization suggests inability to find a stable comfort point
Description: If temperature trends show continuous oscillation or drift without converging, it indicates users have not settled on a comfortable, repeatable setting.
short rationale: Indicates ongoing discomfort and experimentation.

Inference: Distinct morning vs evening temperature ranges indicate dual comfort baselines
Description: If morning temperatures consistently fall in one range and evening in another, it suggests users maintain different comfort expectations at different times of day.
short rationale: Exposes dual daily comfort baselines and routines.
